Every body continues in its state of rest unless a force forces it to change that state.

What is the conversion of units?

<html> <head></head> <body style="text-align:justify;color:#000;background-color:#fff;"> The conversion of units is the transformation of a quantity, expressed in a certain unit of measurement, into another equivalent. It can be from the same system of units or not. </br></br>This process is usually done with the use of conversion factors and conversion tables. It is often enough to multiply by a fraction and the result is another equivalent measure, in which the units have changed. </body> </html>

<html> <head></head> <body style="text-align:justify;color:#000;background-color:#fff;"> When the change of units involves the transformation of several units, several conversion factors can be used one after the other. </body> </html>
<html> <head></head> <body style="text-align:justify;color:#000;background-color:#fff;"> In this way, the final result will be the equivalent measure of the units sought. </body> </html>

A vector is every line segment directed in space. Each vector has characteristics that are:
  1. Origin or also called Point of application. It is the exact point on which the vector acts.
  2. Module is the length or size of the vector.
  3. Direction is given by the orientation in the space of the line that contains it.
  4. Sense is indicated by an arrowhead located at the end of the vector, indicating to which side of the line of action the vector is directed.

" <html> <head></head> <body style="text-align:justify;color:#000;background-color:#fff;"> The study of vectors is facilitated if we place them in a Cartesian decorating system that helps us to have greater precision, so as to be able to represent them in an algebraic way as well as in a geometric way. </body> </html> "

" <html> <head></head> <body style="text-align:justify;color:#000;background-color:#fff;"> One of the characteristics is that when we have a vector that is not at the origin of our Cartesian plane, we can move it, so that the origin is always (0,0) andthus facilitate our calculations, because we will only need the end point to determine it. </body> </html> "

" <html> <head></head> <body style="text-align:justify;color:#000;background-color:#fff;"> Like numbers, vectors can be operated on each other, through addition, subtraction, multiplication by a scalar, division by a scalar, product point and cross product. These last two are typical of vectors. </body> </html> "

" <html> <head></head> <body style="text-align:justify;color:#000;background-color:#fff;"> When adding two vectors, another vector is obtained (sum or resultant vector). To obtain the sum vector it is necessary to resort to what is known as the "parallelogram rule". That is, a parallelogram is constructed that has the vectors as sides and the diagonal is drawn to obtain the vector sum. </body> </html> "

" If we want to add A + B, one is drawn after the other, moving it. The resulting vector is the one that goes from the initial point of the first vector to the end of the last one. It should be noted that the sum is commutative, that is:
A + B = B + A

When you want to add more than one vector, you proceed in the same way as before, but now they are placed one after the other until the last one. Then the line that joins the beginning of the first vector with the term of the last one is the resulting vector. "

" <html> <head></head> <body style="text-align:justify;color:#000;background-color:#fff;"> It is based on writing a vector as the sum of two others which are orthogonal (perpendicular to each other), for this it is based on the Cartesian plane, the vectors that are added are in one of the axes. The rectangular components are so called because it is based on the construction of a rectangle. </body> </html> "

" In the image you can see that the vector A is not more than the sum of one vector on the "X" axis and another one on the "Y" axis. Each of these vectors is known as the component, so the vector Ax is the component "X" of the vector A.

In order to write these vectors correctly, we must introduce the unit vectors, which are detailed below. "

" Let two vectors A and B be added, then we proceed in the graphical way that we know, which gives us as a result the vector R.

Now what we will do is write both the vector A and the B according to its components, then we realize that the sum of the components "X" of vector A and B, is the component " X " of the vector R and thus also with the axis " Y ". "

" Therefore, to add vectors in an algebraic way, write each vector according to its components and then add the components "X" and "Y" of the vectors, the result will be the resulting vector according to its components, with which the module of the vector R can be extracted. "

" They are easy to recognize physical magnitudes, since to identify them we only need to know their magnitude, in some cases it is necessary to accompany them in the unit of measurement like the ones mentioned below.
Examples: speed, mass, time, distance, area, perimeter, density, volume, temperature, etc. "

" <html> <head></head> <body style="text-align:justify;color:#000;background-color:#fff;"> Is one that, in addition to a numerical value and its units (module) we must specify its direction and meaning. </body> </html> "

"

Fundamental magnitudes


The fundamental units are defined independently and, often, the quantities are directly measurable in a physical system. They do not depend on any other physical magnitude.

There are a total of seven fundamental magnitudes:

Mass:
kilogram (kg) It is defined by the mass of a platinum-iridium cylinder prototype maintained at the International Bureau of Weights and Measures in Paris, France.

Length:
meter (m) It is defined as the length of the path traveled by light in a range of exactly 1/299792458 seconds.

Time:
second (s) According to the International System of Units, it is the time of 192,631,770 periods of oscillations of the light emitted by a cesium -133 atoms corresponds to the transition between two hyperfine levels of the ground state.

Electric current:
ampere (A) Measure the intensity of electric current. It is defined by the constant current that if it flows in two parallel straight conductors of infinite length and negligible section circulates, when it is 1 meter away in the vacuum, it produces a force equal to 2 × 10-7 Newton per meter of length between these drivers.

Temperature:
kelvin (K) According to the International System of Units, the kelvin is exactly 1 / 273.16 of the thermodynamic temperature of the triple point of water.

Luminous intensity:
candela (cd) It measures the light intensity of a source that emits a radiation of a constant frequency of 540 × 1012 Hz with a radiant intensity of 1/683 watts per stereo in any given direction.

mol
(mol) The mole is the amount of substance that contains as many entities as atoms in 0.012 kg of carbon-12.

"

"

Derived quantities


The derived quantities are formed by the product of the powers of the fundamental units, these units are not defined independently, since they depend on the definition of other units. Except for the 7 fundamental magnitudes named above, all other magnitudes are derived. Some examples of derived quantities are:

Unit of work: joule or July (J) It is the work done when the point of application of the force of a newton (1 N) moves at a distance of one meter (1 m) in the direction of force.

Strength: newton (N) It is that force that, when applied to a body with a mass of one kilogram (1 kg), gives an acceleration of one meter per second squared (1 mx s2 ).

Pressure: pascal (Pa) It is the pressure that results when a force of a newton (1 N) is applied uniformly and perpendicularly to a surface of one square meter (1 m2).

Electrical potential: volt (V) It is the potential difference between two points of a conduction cable that carries a constant current of one ampere (1 A), when the power dissipated between these points is one Watt (1 W).

"

" <html> <head></head> <body style="text-align:justify;color:#000;background-color:#fff;"> “Every free body, over which no force acts, maintains its state of movement, either at rest, or in a uniform rectilinear motion.” </body> </html> "

" <html> <head></head> <body style="text-align:justify;color:#000;background-color:#fff;"> The principle of inertia is fulfilled when no forces act on a body or when the acting forces counteract each other. Concisely, this law postulates that a body can not change its initial state by itself, either in rest or in uniform rectilinear motion, unless a force or a series of forces is applied resulting is not null about it. </br></br> In reality, it is impossible to find an inertial reference system, since there is always some kind of forces acting on the bodies, but it is always possible to find a reference system in which the problem that we are studying can be treated as if we were in an inertial system. In many In some cases, supposing a fixed observer on Earth is a good approximation of the inertial system. </body> </html> "

" “Every body on which a force acts moves in such a way that the variation of its The amount of movement with respect to time is equal to the force produced by the movement.” He express with the following formula:

F=a*m "

" <html> <head></head> <body style="text-align:justify;color:#000;background-color:#fff;"> In which m is mass, force and acceleration. The last two are Vector magnitudes. </br></br> If several forces act simultaneously on a body, we can also apply the fundamental formula of the dynamics. In this case, the force that appears in the first member will result from all the forces to which the body is submitted. </br></br> Newton's Second Law is responsible for quantifying the concept of force. Us says that the net force applied to a body is proportional to the acceleration that acquires said body. </br></br> The expression of Newton's Second Law that we have given is valid for bodies whose mass is constant. If the mass varies, such as a rocket that is burning fuel, the relation F = m · a is not valid. </body> </html> "

" <html> <head></head> <body style="text-align:justify;color:#000;background-color:#fff;"> Law of action and reaction With every action there is always an equal and opposite reaction: that is, actions Mutuals of two bodies are always the same and directed in the opposite direction. </br></br> Also known as Principle of action and reaction tells us essentially that if a body A exerts an action on another body B, this one performs on A another equal and opposite action. </br></br> It states that for each force acting on a body, it performs a force of equal intensity and direction, but in the opposite direction on the body that produced it. Said another form, the forces, located on the same line, are always presented in pairs of equal magnitude and opposite in sense. </br></br> This law is something that we can check daily on numerous occasions. By example, when we want to jump up, we push the ground to boost us The reaction of the soil is what makes us jump up. </body> </html> "
select with which unit of measure these fundamental quantities are represented:
a rope passes over a pulley without friction and with negligible mass. A 4.0 kg object hangs on one end and on the other a 12 kg object. Calculate the acceleration and tension of the rope.

An elevator part of the rest and goes up with a constant acceleration. It moves 2.0cm in the first 0.60s. a passenger in the elevator holds a 3 kg package with a rope. What is the tension in the rope during acceleration?
Once lit, a small rocket engine of a spacecraft exerts a constant force of 10 N for 7.80 s. During the time it burns, the rocket makes the 100-kg ship accelerate evenly. Determine that acceleration.

A bullet of 12.0 g is accelerated from rest to a speed of 700m / s when traveling 20.0cm inside the rifle barrel. Assuming that the acceleration is constant, how large should the accelerating force be?
Enter your answer without decimal points
select with which unit of measure these derived quantities are represented:
A 900 kg car travels at 20m/s on a flat road. What is the magnitude of a constant retarding force necessary to stop the car in a distance of 30m? (suggestion: first calculate the deceleration.)
Two forces act on a point object in the following way: 100N at 170 degrees and 100N at 50 degrees. Do you calculate your result?
Algebraically calculate the resultant of the following coplanar displacements: 20m at 30 degrees, 40m at 120 degrees, 25m at 180 degrees, 42m at 270 degrees and 12m at 315 degrees.
What displacement must be added to another 50 cm in the + x direction so that the resulting displacement is 85 cm at 28 degrees?
The x component of a displacement is 450m. Calculate the resulting displacement from 85cm to 25 degrees?
With the obtained mass the values are changed in the formula a = fr / m

Two boxes of 20 and 30 kg of masses, respectively, are supported on a horizontal surface without friction, one resting on the other. If we push the set with a force of 100N. What is the acceleration of each other? What force will each box exercise over the other?
On the box 1 act the forces F and F21 in the horizontal direction and on the box 2, the F12 in the same direction. In module F21 = F12.
Applying Newton\'s 2nd law F = m * a; to each box:
box1: F-F21 = m1 * to box2: F12 = m2 * a Addition: F = (m1 + m2) * a; 100 = (20 + 30) * a; a = 2m / s²
And substituting in f12 = m2 * a = 20 * 2 = 40N, force exerted by box 1 over 2. The force exerted by box 2 over 1 is equal in module, direction and opposite direction
